title: What is the best Kate Bush song? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah, Kate Bush. The leotard nymph. The bad babooshka. The mad companion of hounds. Deciding which of this brilliant woman’s many compositions is the best, is no easy task. I mean, you’d think it would be an easy task. Just yell the name of one of her famous singles and be done with it. Do yourself a favour and don’t think too much about the obvious, right? Wrong. The Bush won’t reveal her true greatness without a lot of trimming first.One simply does not put ones finger in there and point at the obvious choce!An artists of this caliber deserves to be respected and analyzed.It’s what Kate herself did when she drew inspiration for her own songs, so it seems only right that I should analyze her work as well, before I decide which delicious melody of hers brings me the most pleasure. And to do this, I will have to go through EVERY song she’s written.I will judge them as I see fit, and then I’ll collect all the best songs from each album and have them battle it out for the top spot. I will not include unofficial home demo recordings.Nor will I include cover songs performed by Kate, like Elton John’s Rocket Man. This is all about the Bush’s tush. So without further ado, let’s get cracking! The Kick Inside  Moving - Sounds more detached to me. But also vaguely Chinese. Good. 4/5The Saxophone Song - Unique and girly melody, with aggressive sax. 4/5Strange Phenomena - Like a Broadway musical for Chinese toddlers. 3/5Kite - Upbeat and catchy reggae. Filled with playful enthusiasm. 4/5The Man with the Child In His Eyes - Kate wrote it, aged 13! WTF? 4/5Wuthering Heights - Otherworldly. Progressive. Beautiful. Haunting. 5/5James and the Cold Gun - Surprisingly hard-hitting rocker. Not bad. 4/5Feel It - Sorry, I’m not feeling it. This is too girly for me. 3/5Oh to Be in Love - A great song with a not so great chorus. 4/5L’Amour Looks Something Like You - Remarkably mature ballad. 4/5Them Heavy People - It’s a good song. But it annoys me as well. 4/5Room for the Life - This is the greatest song ever written about a womb. 5/5The Kick Inside - Pleasant little ballad to close the album with. 4/5The Kick Inside is a stunning debut from someone so young. Not only are the songs very accomplished, but there’s a consistent “Asian” style to most of them (even the album cover fits this theme) which makes for a very coherent listening experience. “Room for the Life” is one of the most underrated gems she’s ever written, in my opinion, and I’d love to choose that. But “Wuthering Heights” is the obvious winner here. Lionheart  Symphony in Blue - Unfairly ignored single. Kate admits to liking sex. 4/5In Search of Peter Pan -Kate shows us the way to Neverland. 3/5Wow - Sounds like an Elton John Broadway number. Classic. 4/5Don’t Push Your Foot on the Heartbrake - Kate can’t sing hard rock. 2/5Oh England My Lionheart - Slightly medieval, I suppose. 3/5Full House - Progressive rock/jazz fusion. A clear highlight here. 4/5In the Warm Room - Nice and cozy little song. No more than that. 3/5Kashka from Baghdad - It’s fine. Kate sounds bored and uninterested. 3/5Coffee Homeground - Nazi carnival music. Good fun. 4/5Hammer Horror - Fine song. Kate doesn’t sing it very well, though. 3/5Lionheart was unfairly compared with her debut album and was considered a bit of a disappointment at the time. The songs are nowhere near as memorable this time around, but that doesn’t mean that they’re bad.Once again, there’s a consistent theme to the way all the songs sound.I like to think of it as “autumnal music” or something. And I LOVE the album cover. Hmm, “Full House” is the song I respect the most here, but I’m choosing “Wow”because I think it has wider appeal to you boys and girls. Never for Ever  Babooshka - A highly sophisticated composition. Impressive and fun. 5/5Delius (Song of Summer) - Delius never wrote something this good. 5/5Blow Away - Like blowing on a psychedelic dandelions or something. 4/5All We Ever Look For - Moving little musical performed by critters. 5/5Egypt - Any song with a “Pussy Queen” in it, is immediately good. 4/5The Wedding List - Complex song about a simple revenge tale. 3/5Violin - Having an orgasm in the orchestra pit again, Kate? 3/5The Infant Kiss - Gorgeous melody. Also available in a French version. 5/5Night Scented Stock - Not a song but a short, beautiful interlude. 3/5Army Dreamers - One of the most understated war songs ever. 4/5Breathing - Progressive environmentalist masterpiece. 4/5Kate’s third album feels like the final part of a trilogy to me.The songwriting remains consistently mysterious throughout and the productionis, again, rather “autumnal” to my ears. And the album cover is spectacular. “Babooshka” is the obvious choice here. It’s such a classy song. It has to win. The Dreaming  Sat in Your Lap - Aggressive and pissed off. Furious drums. Great. 5/5There Goes a Tenner - Catchy sky number about scared bank robbers. 4/5Pull Out the Pin - Kate and David Gilmour fight in the Vietnam war? 4/5Suspended in Gaffa - I always love a footstomper, and this one is great. 5/5Leave it Open - Sounds like a Led Zeppelin song in disguise. 4/5The Dreaming - What the fuck did you put on the barbie? 4/5Night of the Swallow - A blues ballad AND an Irish jig? But, of course! 4/5All the Love - Is it about dying and guilt? Who the hell knows. 3/5Houdini - Great song about a foolish man. 4/5Get out of My House - Hell hath no fury like a donkey scorned. 4/5Angry, difficult, complex, bizarre and outrageous, “The Dreaming” isn’t so much about individual songs as it is about surviving the experience of listening to all of it.Nevertheless, there are a couple of easily digestible moments on it, and chief amongthem is probably “Suspended in Gaffa” so that’s the one I’ll go with. Hounds of Love  Running Up That Hill (A Deal with God) - Hypothetical gender swapping. 5/5Hounds of Love - Utterly brilliant and highly evocative and romantic. 5/5The Big Sky - Just an apocalyptic jam, really. The 12-inch is superior. 5/5Mother Stands for Comfort - Sorry, mummy. I love you. 5/5Cloudbusting - Pop perfection. Arguably the peak of Kate’s career. 5/5And Dream of Sheep - Slowly freezing to death sounds wonderful. 5/5Under Ice - Wait, it sounds like a bloody nightmare!! Aah! Cellos! 5/5Waking the Witch - Well, she’s awake. And you’re on trial for your life. 4/5Watching You Without Me - Somber meditation on people you miss. 5/5Jig of Life - Kate’s the master of the demonic Irish jig. 5/5Hello Earth - Watching yourself drown from outer space. 5/5The Morning Fog - We (probably) survived. But harps are playing… 5/5Commonly regarded as Kate’s masterpiece and one of the greatest albums of the 80’s, selecting a winning song from this beast of an album is no easy task!It’s between “Hounds of Love” and “Cloudbusting” for me. But since you’re pointing a gun at my balls, I guess I’ll go with “Cloudbusting” because it’s the more epic in scope of the two songs, and I find it emotionally overwhelming.Which is always good. The Sensual World  The Sensual World - Suitably sensual and seductive ballad. 5/5Love and Anger - Incredible song with some nice Gilmour guitar. 5/5The Fog - Apt title. The song is like a symphonic fog to get lost in. 4/5Reaching Out - Soulful ballad with some really great singing. 5/5Heads We’re Dancing - May I have this dance, Hitler? Hmm. 3/5Deeper Understanding - Tinder pre-Internet. Better than it sounds. 5/5Between a Man and a Woman - Wow. A boring Kate Bush song. 2/5Never Be Mine - Another lovely ballad. Dreamlike. 5/5Rocket’s Tail - Bulgarian singing gives way to almost demented rock. 5/5This Woman’s Work - If I was a woman, this would be my funeral song. 5/5Walk Straight Down the Middle - Bluesy song with some funny vocals. 4/5Following up something like Hounds of Love is not something that anyone canjust do on command. Not even Kate could come up with something that matched or outdid what she’d done before. But after 4 years, she did release an album that was almost as good, in many ways, and in “This Woman’s Work” she arguably wrote the most beautiful ballad ever written. So I’ll have to choose that. The Red Shoes  Rubberband Girl - The stretchiest pop song you’ll ever hear! 5/5And So is Love - Some truly passionate singing on this one. 4/5Eat the Music - Calypso and fruit. Very catchy and very good. 5/5Moments of Pleasure - Sometimes it’s good to be sentimental. 5/5Song of Solomon - It’s fine, I guess. Nothing special. 3/5Lily - Almost good. Mostly bad. That’s no good. Makes me sad. 3/5The Red Shoes - The old film had better music for this scene. 3/5Top of the City - Lost among skyscrapers, the girl sings the blues. 4/5Constellation of the Heart - Mediocre song. Truly awful. 2/5Big Stripey Lie - Worst song of her career. Nigel Kennedy’s on it… 1/5Why Should I Love You? - Why would work with Prince? Bad idea. 2/5You’re the One - Phew. At least the album ends with a banger. 5/5I can certainly see why Bush would be attracted to the story of the Red Shoes,and why she’d want to make both her own music and film to portray that storyin her own way. But the result wasn’t the best. Some of the music is OK, but it doesn’t suit the story, in my opinion, and Kate isn’t a great dramatic actress, as evidenced byher somewhat absent-minded and confused performance in her directorial debut, “The Line, The Cross and the Curve”. Many of the songs on the album go hand in hand with the film. It’s all one big concept. So I’m just going to choose “You’re the One” because it has nothing to do with the story of the film at all. It’s just a wonderful ballad. Aerial  King of the Mountain - Decent reggae song about….Elvis? 3/5π - About as exciting as calculus. 1/5Bertie - Excruciating song about her son. Make it stop. 1/5Mrs. Bartolozzi - Throwback to her early piano days. Washing machine! 2/5How to Be Invisible - You slow down the Beatles’ “Get Back” apparently. 2/5Joanni - Long chords and a lot of mumbling. Some of it in French. 2/5A Coral Room - Boring piano ballad without focus or character. 2/5Prelude - Dove mating calls can be heard over piano. 1/5Prologue - More mumbling. In Italian this time. 2/5An Architect’s Dream - Bossa nova preset on your keyboard is better. 2/5The Painter’s Link - Kate and some dude sing about colours. 2/5Sunset - First listenable song on the album. It has energy! 3/5Aerial Tal - Kate imitates asshole bird. Her son laughs. 1/5Somewhere in Between - Finally a good song. More of this, please! 4/5Nocturn - And more we get! This is funky and sexy. Great bass.4/5Aerial - And we end with what sounds like Kate’s version of rave music. 4/5I can remember being extremely excited when this album was released in 2005, 12 years after The Red Shoes. And I can also remember being extremely disappointed by it. It was Kate’s first double album, and it was just about sunshine and being a happy mother All the darkness was gone. All the passion and mystery replaced with domestic bullshit. And to this day, I can’t fucking stand it. However, a song must be chosen, so I’ll go with “Somewhere in Between”. 50 Words for Snow  Snowflake - Sounds like being trapped with a choirboy under snow. 2/5Lake Tahoe - Well, there’s piano chords in it. 1/5Misty - Wow, drums and bass! This is getting exciting! 1/5Wild Man - The Hakuna Matata choir is jerking off in the snow. 1/5Snowed in at Wheeler Street - Elton John shows up. Poor guy. 1/550 Words for Snow - Stephen Fry reads out a list of words for snow. 1/5Among Angels - Nothing redeemable about this one. 1/5Quite frankly, this is the worst album Kate’s ever made, and if someone else madeit; someone who didn’t have the legacy she has, then I’d demand they’d be shot.Finding the “best” song on this album is impossible. I refuse.There’s NOTHING good here at all. Fuck this album to hell. Sigh. Let’s end with something more positivie. This Woman’s Work - Volume One  The Empty Bullring - Charming and playful piano tune. 4/5Ran Tan Waltz - Sounds like a drunken, German waltz. 4/5Passing Through Air - Kate trying to sound generic. 2/5December Will Be Magic Again - Decent Christmas song. 4/5Warm and Soothing - Yup, it’s a piano ballad. 4/5Lord of the Reedy River - Pan flutes and mumbling. 2/5Ne T'enfuis Pas - Nice little song in French. Nothing more. 4/5Under the Ivy - Hounds of Love outtake. It’s good. 4/5Burning Bridge - Sounds like a bad demo of “The Big Sky”. 3/5My Lagan Love - Kate sings a cappella. Sometimes that’s enough. 4/5The Handsome Cabin Boy - A cappella again, except for a synth. 4/5Not This Time - Couldn’t agree more. 2/5Be Kind to My Mistakes - Sorry. Not when they’re this boring. 2/5This Woman’s Work - Volume Two  I’m Still Waiting - Should’ve been on “The Sensual World”. 4/5Ken - Written for the Comic Strip film of the same name. Bad. 2/5One Last Look Around the House Before We Go - Instrumental. 3/5Experiment IV - This is a pretty haunting song. I like it. 4/5Both of these volumes are part of the same box set, so I will only chooseone song from both of them to represent Kate’s B-sides.And the best of the lot is “Under the Ivy”. And there we have it. I didn’t include Kate’s 2011 “Director’s Cut” album becausenone of the songs on it are new. She’s just been fucking around with perfection like some musical George Lucas… OK. Let’s round up the best songs. Wuthering HeightsWowBabooshkaSuspended in GaffaCloudbustingThis Woman’s WorkYou’re the OneSomewhere in BetweenUnder the IvyYeah, it’s not easy, is it? “Wuthering Heights” would probably be a lot of people’s first choice, and understandably so. It’s a classic for a reason. But it’s also TOO obvious.“Cloudbusting” is the best song on her best album, so that immediately pushes it high up on the list. On the other hand, “This Woman’s Work” is almost certainly the most beautiful ballad I’ve ever heard, so… Fuck it. I’m going to have to cheat on this one.Instead of choosing THE greatest Kate Bush song of them all, I’ll choose the bestfrom each of the different genres she usually writes in. Best ethereal pop song: Wuthering Heights. Best pop song: Cloudbusting Best piano ballad: This Woman’s Work Yeah, I know. It’s a cop-out, but how do you choose between 3 perfect songs?They’re all equally important, moving and effective on different days at different times, depending on what mood you’re in.

Kate Bush is a supremely talented musician, singer and performer but I feel that her extraordinary ability as a lyricist is often overlooked. She tackles many different themes, each with artistry that other writers could only dream of. Just a few examples include:- Poignancy: This Woman’s Work, The Man With The Child In His Eyes, Apocalypse: Experiment IV, Breathing Revenge: Babooshka Nonsense: Fifty Words For Snow Loss: A Coral Room, Army Dreamers Of course, there are some songs whose lyrics seem so obtuse that I suspect only she knows what they are really about. For me these include Running Up That Hill, Sat In Your Lap, King Of The Mountain and quite a few more. If I had to pick one song that pulled together all of Kate’s extraordinary gifts and vision, AND which took popular music to a place it had never gone before, I would pick Rocket’s Tail from her 1989 album The Sensual World. It still send shivers down my spine more than 30 years after it was first released.
